reviewText:
This game is good.
This game is good!
This game is good?

Yep. Saviors, the 19 cent 2D shootemup, is good. I was not expecting this. No really, I was looking forward to tearing this game to pieces. Unfortunately for me, the only worthy complaint is the terrible character-models and bland art-direction. Once I actually played the game, it all came together quite nicely. This is a legitimately decent indie shooter.

Humanity is doomed AGAIN, or maybe they're not doomed, or maybe I don't care. This threadbare and easily ignorable plot sets up 15 stages of shooting action. For an arcade 2D shooter, that's quite a lot. Thankfully, these stages are well-paced, with only 5 of them having real boss-fights. Furthermore, your first experience with this game is liable to be the story mode, where the large number of stages seems a bit more sensible.

In story mode, you're given the choice of three pilots, each with their own ship. As you play through the stages, you'll gather experience, which leads to level-up perks. Also, in-between stages you can decide on primary, secondary, and side weapons. There's an interesting amount of strategy, that's tempered by good old-fashioned reflexes. The better you do, the higher your score, which also ties into your experience. The level of difficulty can also be changed, just in case things get too easy or too difficult. The other modes remove the stage to stage decision-making. Instead you're given a choice between various ships and weapon-systems. All you have to do is select the setup that suits your play-style.

With Saviors, unlike most shooters, you always have an idea of what's approaching. There are constant indicators for every enemy ship, so you can focus on either destroying them immediately, or let them stay on-screen for a bit, so you can maintain your chain combo. Each ship has their own arsenal and pattern. As you progress you'll face newer ships in greater numbers. Another aspect that is unlike most shooters is the fact that you get a shield. Obviously it's not something to be relied upon, but it comes in handy for those stray shots. The boss-fights tend to be bullet-hell affairs. All you really have to do is hang back, fire away, and dodge for seemingly an eternity. For most players, the normal difficulty provides a sufficient challenge.

reviewText:
At first glance the game looks like something made in 1995 and upscaled to HD. The price is also suspiciously low. But don't let that fool you, because Star Staviors is a surprisingly decent and well made indie shmup, with a lot to offer.

The game is clearly inspired by some of the more popular titles in the genre, in a good way. It is simple and easy to get into, yet offers numerous game modes, difficulties, ship types and weapons to choose from. From what I've played on normal it seems fair, and the controls are responsive enough. The challenge is there, the shooting is enjoyable, and numerous achievements and modes encourage multiple playthroughs.

The game surely is not perfect and could have been improved in some areas, but as a whole it is really good. Simply put, I've had a lot of fun with with it. More so than with many other shmups, that are way more expensive and more hyped up. Great and catchy soundtrack also certainly adds a lot to the overall enjoyment.

The CG avatars are bad.  Even the animation.  Why would they go that route when 2D animation would have served the same function and looked way better?

Things I love in shmups.  Power-ups and Bosses.  Refreshingly, the power-ups you choose don't stay anchored to you.  You're free to mix it up before any level.  You earn new power-ups by performing better in the level via score and score multipliers.

It's a pretty simple formula.  If you do well, fun++.

I only went against a few bosses, but they all had their own patterns that required to be learned.

It's very easy to recommend Saviors if you like Shmups / Bullet-Hells.

reviewText:
This is a very solid shooter experience, and it was made by just three people.  This is exactly the sort of gem you hope to find from small indie teams.

The graphics and music are above average, the control is tight, there are a lot of options to customize your experience, and several different game modes to keep you going.

There are 18 levels to complete to make it through the story.  After each mission you are allowed to pick perks, as well as customize your main, secondary and special weapon.  As you get deeper in the game more options unlock.  You can also choose one of three pilots, and each ship has its own unique flavor.  Missions are a mix of standard enemies and bosses.  Most moves are telegraphed ahead of time, giving you a split second to plan your next move.  You can also alternate your fire between going all guns forward for full damage, or split your damage three ways and shoot ahead of you and to each side.

The story sections are the weakest portion of the game.  There is nothing unique, the writing is not very natural, and the pilots don't look great in the speaking sections.  There is an alien invasion, and only your commander saw it coming, now go blow everything up.  The end.  Fortunately, all story sections can be skipped.

Very worthwhile game if you enjoy this type of shooter.  A solid entry, give it a try.

9/10

reviewText:
Star Saviors another one of the bullet hell genre of games, does it do anything more than what others have done ? no. But it is fun like others ? like hell it is (no pun intended).

Graphics - Buller hell games really don't need that much graphic power, with using simple meshes (like this game does) it works perfectly. But this just can't be overlooked, the character models are taken out of a nightmare, and just put in there to haunt you for the rest of your life. If you can just pass this simple detail, everything else is fine. 6/10

Music - Empowering, just the music it needs for the type of game it is. Mostly heard is metal, with a few dubstep sounds mixed within. If you love that kind of music, you are going to love this game. 7/10

Cinematics - None

Story - You as the reader, have probably heard this story over and over again, the story where you are the chosen one and you have to save the world. Now this may come as a suprise, but this game actually changes it (no it doesn't). You follow a relatively average campaign through the galaxy to prevent a war that is going to unfold at any moment. Also the game tells you multiple times that you are the chosen one, and that you are the only one who can do what you are doing. Although at the start of the campaing, you are given the choice between 3 characters, and while you are doing what you are doing, the other 2 characters are doing the same, but remember how you are the only one capable of doing this ? Well you are not. 5/10

Content - For a game this cheap, it does have quite a bit of stuff hidden within it. A story campaign, which is roughly 18 missions, 3 character choices at the start, which have quite a bit of background story to them. Futhermore, the more you advance through the story, the more weapons and perks you unlock for your skills. Oh forgot to mention that each of the playable characters have a different playstyle. The first one is slow but with hard hiting weapons, the other one is fast with low to average damage, and the last one is average speed with average damage. Also it does other modes, separate from the campaign one. 8/10

Controls - Responds perfectly to any command that you give, which is a must have for these type of games. 8/10

Gameplay - Really fast paced, you don't have time to think about what you are going to do, as you are bombarded all the time. It does get progressively harder with every level, as it is expected. The bosses man were they hard, mostly that one at the 13'th level, but nothing a second (if only it were 2 tries) attempt couldn't fix. 7/10

In spite of that, Star Saviors is a pretty solid entry for a game this cheap. It does have its flaws as does every game, but it does way too many things really well, that you can just look past the flaws. If you like these type of games, you won't regret buying this one.

Final Score: 6.8/10

reviewText:
The game's mechanics are terrible. The enemies simply use your keyboard input as a targeting mechanic, the result being similar to the simple plastic mechanical games that you used to find at dollar stores. I was a huge fan of Galaga. I played it wherever I could find it. My friends always knew when I was younger that, if I went missing, to just look for the closest Galaga game. I love the format, but this doesn't do it justice.

Beyond that, I found the dialog irritating. The author seemed to think they were being witty, or tongue-and-cheek, but it just came across as childish and ignorant. What the teacher says during the tutorial, for instance, stands behind the premise that you have somehow forgotten what you're doing and constantly surfaces how silly it is. The author is trying to say that tutorials are silly in the first-place, as your character should already know what they're doing. Of course, a tutorial is always needed when undertaking a new task. Why would we assume our character isn't just learning how to fly a ship? Why would we imply that they already know how to fly one, but have just forgotten for some reason?

Sorry, I just had to rant. It's a top-down shooter; you could care less about the dialog. So, then, in conclusion: This game is a horrible example of the format with nothing to elevate it beyond others in its genre and isn't worth the 19 cents I paid for it. I've uninstalled it and can safely say that not even the most boring of Saturday afternoons can make me second-guess that decision.

This is the euro STG style done RIGHT! Specifically the european PC breed of shooters with RPG elements. Fair bullet patterns, lots of upgrade fun, a full arcade mode and plenty of challenge. Music is awesome if not a bit repetitive. Backgrounds can leave a bit to be desired, but the graphics are mainly in the bullets, which look spectacular, with plenty of colour and variety. Story mode is long, I'm not sure how long, I'm 18 levels in. They're mostly all really well-designed levels, albeit a bit easy on Normal mode. It won't you go back to earlier levels and annihilate ♥♥♥♥ with your upgraded weapons, and you only earn upgrades if you survive the level you're playing. This is just a review from a personal perspective. :3 Whatever is in the pros and cons are up to debate.

If you like bullet hell games, you can't go wrong with this one.
Pros:
-A true bullet hell game
-fantastic music
-Not too easy, not impossible either
-an okay-ish story
-Tight controls
-solid 3D graphics
-super cheap for what you get

Literally the only thing I didn't like are the hideous character models, stuff of nightmares I tell you.
An absolute yes!

Besides the mediocre to somewhat awful graphics and horrendous avatar visuals that can make even Satan himself curl up in fear, the controls are very responsive, gameplay is hella great especially for bullet hell schmup fans, and is overall a fun, cheap game to check out.
